awards.title: World Procurement Leaders Award 2016 (UK, London)
awards.description:
CROSS-FUNCTIONAL COLLABORATION AWARD
Achieving TRUE collaboration across business functions is always an ambitious undertaking, but Philips’ Design for eXcellence (DfX) programme has placed procurement squarely at the centre of a project that’s not only delivering savings but also contributing to an entirely new way of working. Since its inception in 2013, DfX has played a fundamental role in procurement’s ability, in collaboration with other business functions, to address total end-to-end cost. Alongside decision makers from across the business,including marketing, product management, R&D, operations and finance, procurement has used its reach and influence to embrace innovation and unlock potential product cost reductions. By interrogating the way Philips designs, manufacturers and delivers its products and solutions, procurement is perfectly placed to bring that influence to bear across the value chain. With X’ representing the major variables that can impact on total cost over the product life cycle, procurement has set the standard for a company-wide optimisation tool and ensured that this holistic approach is about far more than simply delivering savings. It is, in short, bringing the X factor to procurement.

profile_positions.description:
As VE Program Manager I raised competencies in Value Engineering within Philips Lighting on a global scale, across business groups and the procurement organization. 
Mainly by managing stakeholders and involvement of business and functional leaders, especially those involved in innovation processes, and engaging people in Value Engineering through role modelling, training and coaching. 

I worked with key functions such as Development, Architects, Product Management, Marketing, Quality, Procurement and Operations, and was tightly linked in the “idea to market” (I2M/NPDL) set of processes – from concept development onward.
 
I built the Value Engineering capability in Philips Lighting by regularly and tenaciously reaching out to senior managers in the businesses and actively practice and embed Value Engineering by adopting best Value Engineering practices. 

This was a ‘change management’ role to drive the organization towards better product decisions making between cost and value, and herewith supporting the growth of Philips Lighting!
This all by creating better products with higher margins via training & workshops to the Business Units with the use of VE Tools as Reverse Engineering, Parameter Optimization, Value Analysis, Value Chain Mapping, DFMA, Cost Modelling, Concept Scoping, VOC tree and Spider Mapping.

Impressive number of cost down achieved during all work done, recognized up to top management (ExCo). 

On a global level, I:
• Conducted introductory Level 1 Value Engineering training (3 days sessions)
• Coached prospective Level 2 Value Engineering Experts and ensured they act as a catalyst for change
• Applied Value Engineering in selected new product development projects (NPI), simultaneously striving for cost reduction and product improvement
• Audit and drive forward the deployment of Value Engineering in businesses and R&D sites

During all these activities I achieved my Master Value Engineering L3 level status (highest degree possible).
